Chapter 5, Part 3: Distinguishing Karma, on the occasion of taking up the precepts of the lay devotee.
Verse:
It is said that the precepts of the lay devotee are taken up by declaring oneself to be so, just like the precepts of the fully ordained monk, etc.
Discussion:
One should arouse a sincere and pure mind, make a sincere statement, and declare oneself to be an upÄsaka, saying, May the Venerable one remember me and compassionately protect me.

At that time, one gives rise to the precepts of the lay devotee. Because the precepts are taken up by declaring oneself to be a lay devotee, etc. It is because the sÅ«tra further states, From now until the end of life, I will protect life.
If one becomes a lay devotee by taking the Three Refuges without declaring oneself to be so, then the statement I am a lay devotee would be useless.
In what sense is it said that one protects life?
Because the precepts of individual liberation are obtained by protecting life.
Or, in order to save one's own life, one also does not violate the precepts of the TathÄgata.
Ordinary beings who are about to receive the precepts also have such a firm intention, and even to save their own lives, they will never violate the precepts they have received.
Such a vow can be found in the world.
However, there is a separate recitation that says to abandon taking life.
The meaning of these words is to say to abandon killing and so on, omitting killing and so on, and only speaking of abandoning taking life.

Although they have already obtained the precepts of the lay follower, in order to make them understand the precepts they should learn, they again explain the five aspects of the precepts such as abandoning taking life, causing them to recognize and uphold them diligently.

Just as after a bhiká¹£u has obtained the complete precepts, the heavy precepts are explained, causing them to recognize and uphold them diligently. The same is so for the Å›rÄmaá¹‡era. This should also be so.
Therefore, the lay follower must possess the precepts. It is not the case that by taking refuge one immediately becomes a lay follower.
Verse:
If all possess the precepts, why speak of the first part, etc.?
It is said based on the ability to uphold.
Treatise:
Here, those who hate the meaning of the Dharma do not rejoice in their minds and raise this objection:

If all lay followers are fully endowed with the precepts, why did the World-Honored One say there are four kinds: those who can learn one part, those who can learn a small part, those who can learn a large part, and those who can learn the full part?
How is it not already proven by this that one does not become a lay follower merely by taking the Three Refuges?

If there is a separate [category] where one becomes a lay follower by simply taking the Three Refuges, then such a lay follower is not included in the previously mentioned four kinds, and one should speak of a fifth kind of lay follower.
This [fifth kind] has nothing to learn in the precepts, and one should also speak of it as a single lay follower.
The Buddha observed that a lay follower is not separate from the precepts, and therefore the sutras only speak of four kinds.
Although all lay followers are fully endowed with the precepts, they are still spoken of as four kinds based on their ability to uphold [the precepts].

That is, although one may fully receive the five-part discipline, later encountering conditions one may then violate or break it. Among them, some may be able to uphold one part of the precepts, up to some who fully uphold the five parts. Therefore, it is said:
Because one can uphold what was previously received, it is said that one can study.
Otherwise, one should say upholding one part and so on. Therefore, these four kinds are based only on what can be upheld.
However, the commentator says:
It is said that upholding and violating precepts are called one part and so on.
It is not even a question, let alone a proper answer.

Who, having already understood that the discipline of the lay follower necessarily has five parts, would not understand that upholding one part of the precepts but not the others, up to fully upholding them, is called one part and so on?
Because they have not yet understood the amount of receiving the discipline of the lay follower, they should ask:
How many kinds of upÄsakas are there who can study the precepts?
The answer is:
There are four kinds of upÄsakas, namely those who can study one part and so on. They still do not understand.
He further asked:
What is meant by being able to train in one part?
And so on, explaining in detail. This is completely unreasonable, because it should ask and answer only within the principles explained by the Abhidharma school.
Although it is known that the lay follower must possess the precepts, it is still not understood whether by violating one, one violates all, or only one and not the others.
Because of this doubt, it should be asked.
If the various schools have not yet seen this text, they will still argue about this meaning to this day.
If it were otherwise, the Buddha's sÅ«tras would often say:
The upÄsaka is endowed with five precepts.
Who, having understood this well, would still doubt and ask about the number of precepts to be received?
Even if one allows this, it contradicts the question.
That is to say, they originally doubted the number of precepts to be received, but asked how many precepts one can train in.
The answer is training in one part and so on. How could this remove the original doubt?
Therefore, in their meaning, questions and answers should not be asked.

The author of the treatise improperly investigates this, and in the midst of disputes, holds sectarian views, and in turn says that in the meaning explained by the Abhidharma, questions should not even be asked, let alone answered.
If one who lacks discipline is also called a lay follower, then bhiká¹£us and Å›rÄmaá¹‡eras who lack [discipline] should also be established [as such].
However, the author of the treatise says:
Why is it not allowed?
Because the Buddha's teachings are established differently, even if one lacks discipline, one can become a lay follower, but bhiká¹£us and Å›rÄmaá¹‡eras must have discipline.
This is based on one's own feelings, because there is no sÅ«tra that says so.
Where did the World-Honored One say that one can become a lay follower by separating from discipline?
The bhiká¹£us and others have never heard that the SautrÄntika school has this view.

There are also Å›rÄmaá¹‡eras and bhiká¹£us without precepts. Their views should be the same as those of the non-Buddhists such as PÅ«raá¹‡a, not the tenets of the Buddha's teachings. All disciplines are of various kinds, not of the same kind, because there are three grades.
How are they established according to the reason?
Verse:
The lower, middle, and upper [grades] follow the mind.
The treatise says:
The prÄtimoká¹£a precepts received by the eight assemblies are accomplished according to the power of the mind that receives them, and are of lower, middle, or upper grades.
For this reason, among arhats, some may accomplish the lower grade of precepts, while among ordinary beings, some may accomplish the upper grade.
For those who take refuge in the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹…gha, what do they take refuge in?
The verse says:
Taking refuge in the Buddha and Saá¹…gha, the two kinds of dharmas of the adepts,
And nirvÄá¹‡a, cessation through discernment, is said to be the complete three refuges.
The treatise says:
As the Abhidharma treatise states:
For those who take refuge in the Buddha, what dharmas do they take refuge in?

It means that if there are any dharmas that are wonderfully existent and presently existent, and are designated and spoken of by conceptualization and thought, they are called the Buddha. Taking refuge in this can accomplish the non-learner dharmas of the Buddha.
The word if is a general indication of the meaning to be explained.
The word any reveals the supererogatory words of non-self.
The words wonderful existence indicate the nature of wonderful existence, and present existence clarifies the meaning of being presently obtainable.
Alternatively, because of the wonderful virtue and existence, it is called wonderful existence. Present existence reveals that it is the nature of what is to be known.
Conceptualization and so on are different names.
Awakening to the characteristics of all dharmas in all their aspects without relying on the teachings of others is called buddha.
Alternatively, this perfect wisdom and other virtues naturally open to awareness, and so it is called buddha.
Or the name buddha indicates that it has awareness, just as an obstructive object is called having obstruction.
Alternatively, the name buddha indicates that it can speak, opening to awareness in others the awareness that it has realized for itself.
As explained in detail in the Brahma's Questions Sutra.
That which can accomplish buddhahood reveals that those dharmas are the causal basis for the designation and establishment of buddhahood.
How is it that here, among innumerable dharmas, a single name buddha is generally established?
It is not a mistake to establish a single jewel of the Sangha on the basis of many people who are in harmony, or to establish a single aggregate of the path on the basis of many pure paths.
Or, it has already been explained.
What has already been explained?
It is said that the name of a Buddha is established in the unlearned dharmas of the Buddhaâ€™s own continuum, and there is no separate single Buddha who can accomplish the Buddhaâ€™s dharmas.
What are they?

They are the knowledge of exhaustion, etc., and their retinue. Because of attaining that dharma, one is able to awaken to all, and because of its superiority, the body is given the name of a Buddha, not because of the body of form, etc., being the same before and after.
Is it a refuge in a single Buddha or in all Buddhas?
In principle, it should be said that it is a refuge in all Buddhas, because the paths of all Buddhas are not different.
There are five kinds of distinctions in the Sangha: 1) the shameless Sangha, 2) the dumb sheep Sangha, 3) the partisan Sangha, 4) the worldly Sangha, 5) the ultimate Sangha.
The shameless monk refers to a person who violates the precepts but wears the Dharma robes.
The dumb sheep monk refers to a person who has no understanding of the Tripiá¹­aka, like a dumb sheep who has no ability to speak.
Or it is said that dumb means lacking the ability to expound the Dharma.
Moreover, the word sheep is used to show the lack of ability to listen to the Dharma. It shows that this type of person has no ability to listen to or expound the Tripiá¹­aka.
The faction monk refers to a person who skillfully forms factions through wandering, relaxing, working, fighting, and skillful means.
These three types mostly create non-dharma activities.
The worldly monk refers to ordinary beings who are good, who can create both dharma and non-dharma activities.
The ultimate monk refers to the dharmas of learning and no-learning, and the person who is the vessel for them. This definitely does not allow the creation of non-dharma activities.
It is the most excellent of the five, and is the refuge.
As the verses praising taking refuge say:
This refuge is the most excellent, this refuge is the most venerable,
Certainly by relying on this refuge, one can be liberated from all suffering.

Regarding these two kinds of supreme truth of the Saá¹…gha, the intention of KÄtyÄyanÄ«putra is to take the Dharma as the refuge of the Saá¹…gha. Therefore, in the original treatise, it is said: One takes refuge in the training and no-training dharmas that constitute the Saá¹…gha.
There are many kinds of Saá¹…gha, namely, the Saá¹…gha of persons, the Saá¹…gha of Å›rÄvakas, the Saá¹…gha of fields of merit, and the Saá¹…gha of sages, etc.
The Buddha is not the Saá¹…gha of Å›rÄvakas within this, but he can be the other kinds of Saá¹…gha, because he is the one who awakens by himself.
The one who is taken refuge in now is the Saá¹…gha of Å›rÄvakas. In principle, one should take refuge in all the disciples of the Buddhas, because the paths of all the Saá¹…ghas are the same.
However, the sÅ«tras say:

That scripture only reveals that the Sangha Jewel of the future takes refuge in the Dharma, that is, takes refuge in the cessation of nirvana that is the extinction of craving. All such [cessations] are different names for the extinction of afflictions.

Some say that craving is attached to the door of enjoyment and should not be abandoned, so it is used as a metaphor to generally reveal the complete extinction of all afflictions. This is because craving and the other afflictions have the same antidote.
As for the extinction of craving, it means the complete extinction of all craving that is eliminated by the path of seeing.
Therefore, when the stream-enterer extinguishes this craving, he himself declares that all evil destinies are extinguished, saying, I have already extinguished the hells and so forth.
As for separation, it means that in the desire realm, most of the craving that exists has already been eliminated, which means that desire for the desire realm has already become thin.
As for cessation, it means the complete elimination of all craving in the desire realm. This is because at that time, the afflictions of this realm definitely have no binding power.
Nirvana is the eternal cessation of all suffering that occurs when all craving for the form and formless realms is brought to an end.
This passage reveals the four fruits of the religious life. Alternatively, these four kinds of nirvana reveal the cessation of craving in the three realms and the state of eternal quiescence.
The phrase the end of craving refers to the cessation of craving in the three realms.
The phrase separation refers to the cessation of all the passions other than craving.ğŸ”½The phrase cessation reveals the state of nirvana with remainder.
The word nirvana reveals the state of nirvana without remainder.
What is the refuge?ğŸ”½What is the refuge taker?
What is the meaning of taking refuge?

The refuge is the truth of the cessation of suffering and a part of the truth of the path, with the exception of the pure good qualities of the stage of learning of the pratyekabuddha and bodhisattva.
Why are these not the refuge?
Because they are not able to save one from the fear of samsara.
That is, pratyekabuddhas are unable to expound the Dharma and admonish sentient beings to free them from the fear of birth and death.
Bodhisattvas in the stage of learning do not arouse a fixed intention, and therefore they also lack the meaning of being able to admonish others.
Therefore, the dharmas of learning and no-more-learning in their bodies cannot save and protect, and are not the refuge.
Other masters say:
Because they are not united and not manifest, pratyekabuddhas and bodhisattvas are not the refuge, respectively.
Because pure, undefiled thought is also produced in dependence on them, they are also included in the objects of the realization of purity.
Here, the essence of taking refuge is verbal action, because it is by nature the establishment of a vow.
If together with its retinue, it has the five aggregates as its essence, because the words of taking refuge arise from the mind and so on, and do not exist apart from the mind.
In this way, taking refuge has the meaning of saving and rescuing.
How can the holy dharmas and unconditioned good of another's body be able to save and rescue one's own body?
because by taking refuge in them one can put an end to the great fear of the wheel of birth and death.

Third, the three refuges differ in their characteristics. The Buddha is only the post-learner stage. The Dharma is neither. The Sangha is the essence that pervades both the learner and post-learner stages.

Moreover, the essence of the Buddha is a small part of the ten faculties. The Sangha is twelve. The essence of the Dharma is not a faculty, because the unconditioned of cessation is not included in the faculties.
Moreover, taking refuge in the Buddha means only taking refuge in one conditioned fruit of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Taking refuge in the Dharma means universally taking refuge in the four unconditioned fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Taking refuge in the Sangha means universally taking refuge in the four conditioned fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a and the companions who are heading towards the four fruits.
Moreover, the Buddha is like a guide. The Dharma is like the peaceful destination. The Sangha is like companions who travel the right path together.
One should seek the causes for these three differences. One should consider why it is established in other precepts.
The training of the non-brahmacÄrin is to abstain from sexual misconduct.
Verse:
Sexual misconduct is most reprehensible, easy to avoid, and one can obtain non-action.
Treatise:
Only sexual misconduct is extremely reprehensible. This is because it is condemned by the world, as it harms the wives of others, leads to evil destinies, and is not celibacy.
Moreover, sexual misconduct is easy to avoid.
Because householders are attached to desires, it is difficult for them to uphold celibacy.
Observing that they cannot practice for a long time, they are not required to abstain from sexual misconduct.

This is because of the power of repeated practice since beginningless time, sexual desire often arises, and householders often come into contact with desirable objects, making it difficult to restrain themselves. Therefore, they are not required to completely avoid it.
Also, all noble ones definitely obtain the precept of non-action regarding sexual misconduct, because even noble ones who have been reborn do not engage in it.
Abandoning non-celibacy is not like this, therefore, the precepts received by the lay follower are only established as abandoning sexual misconduct.
If it were otherwise, learners who have been reborn would not be able to uphold the precepts of the lay follower.
If a lay follower later again from a teacher, vows to further receive the precept of abandoning non-celibacy, does he obtain the precepts that he has not yet obtained?
Some say:
He obtains these precepts, but this does not make him a lay follower, nor does this cause him to lose the name of a lay follower, nor are his precepts incomplete from before.
Some say: He does not obtain the precepts that he has not yet obtained, but he attains the most excellent virtue of the dhÅ«ta ascetic practices.
The one who attains the most excellent method of abandonment refers to the one who is able to abandon sexual desire.
Because of this, if one is able to abandon one's wife and cultivate pure celibacy, one's efforts are not wasted.

If one has not yet taken a wife or concubine, and universally receives the upÄsaka precepts with regard to sentient beings, then when one later takes a wife or concubine, is it not a violation of the precepts?
Because they are not now possessed by another, like property that belongs to oneself.

That is to say, at this time, by various means such as spells, wealth, and reason, one brings them under one's control and they are not bound to another. How can one be said to violate the precepts with regard to them?
There is another principle. When one takes them now, there is no violation of the previous precepts.
The verse says:
One obtains the precepts according to one's vow, not generally in one's continuum.
The treatise says:
Those who receive the desire realm receive the upÄsaka precepts according to their original vow.
What is the original vow?
It is to abstain from sexual misconduct.
With regard to women possessed by another, one gives rise to the thought that they are possessed by another and engages in improper conduct. This is called violating sexual misconduct.
It is not that with regard to the continuum of all sentient beings one makes the vow:
I will be free from sexual misconduct and obtain the precepts.
How can it be called breaking the precepts now?
Since you have obtained the precepts according to your original vow, how can it be called breaking them now when you are following the practice?

After taking a wife and concubines, one also gives rise to this precept regarding one's own wife, etc., because the precepts of the lay practitioner, etc. are obtained in relation to all sentient beings.
If it were otherwise, one would also not commit the precept against sexual misconduct in relation to one's own wife, at an improper place, time, or manner.
Since there is a violation of the old precepts, there should be no violation of the new precepts. Therefore, the previous objection should not be raised.
Why is it that among the four verbal karmic paths, only refraining from false speech is established?

The precepts for the lay practitioner do not require the avoidance of other forms of divisive speech, etc., because of the three reasons stated above: because false speech is most reprehensible, because it is easy for householders to avoid, and because all noble ones have already attained nonperformance of these actions.
There is another reason. A verse says:
If one is allowed to tell lies, one will transgress all precepts.
The treatise says:
When one is questioned about transgressions of the precepts, if one is allowed to tell lies, one will say, â€œI did not do it.â€
Because of this, one will often violate the precepts.
Therefore, the Buddha, in order to make them maintain the precepts, prohibits all precepts against false speech.
How can one make them feel shame and immediately confess their transgressions when they violate the precepts?

Why are four of the abstentions from natural offenses established as precepts for the lay practitioner, while among the abstentions from proscribed offenses, only the prohibition against drinking alcohol is observed in the precepts for the lay practitioner?
A verse says:
Among the prohibitions, only abstaining from alcohol is taught, in order to protect the other precepts.
The treatise says:
Those who drink alcohol are often unrestrained and cannot protect the other precepts, so in order to protect the other precepts, they are made to abstain from drinking alcohol.
This is because after drinking alcohol, one is said to be negligent, to fall into regret, and to be unable to guard against the five classes of offenses such as pÄrÄjika and so on.

There may be a case where, due to this, one is disturbed and violates all the precepts, like an ocean. The World-Honored One knew that drinking alcohol is the cause for committing all naturally evil acts, because it can harm right mindfulness and right wisdom, and because it can lead to the foolishness of breaking precepts and wrong views. Therefore, among all the prohibitions, he only taught this as a precept for the lay followers.
Therefore, although abstaining from drinking alcohol is included in the prohibitive precepts, in establishing all precepts, it is taught together with abstaining from naturally evil acts.
From what does one obtain the prÄtimoká¹£a discipline?
And from what does one obtain the other two disciplines?
In verse it is said:
One obtains the precepts of the desire realm from all two present [minds],
One obtains the precepts of meditation and the undefiled from the fundamental and always [present minds].
The treatise says:
The precepts of the desire realm refer to the precepts of individual liberation. One obtains these from all fundamental karmic paths and from the proximate past and future.
Obtaining from two means obtaining from two types, namely sentient beings and non-sentient beings, natural offenses and prohibited offenses.
As for natural offenses against sentient beings, they refer to actions such as killing. Prohibited offenses refer to things like sleeping in the same room as a woman.
As for natural offenses against non-sentient beings, they refer to stealing external property. Prohibited offenses refer to things like digging the ground and cutting living grass.

Obtaining from the present means obtaining from the aggregates, sense bases, and elements of the present world, not from the past or future. This is because these precepts arise in the realm of sentient beings, and the past and future are not the realm of sentient beings.

The phrase â€œthe realm of sentient beingsâ€ refers to sentient beings and the realms of aggregates, sense bases, and elements that sentient beings rely on. The internal is what sentient beings rely on, and the external is what sentient beings stop at, because it is not past or future.
If one obtains the precepts of dhyÄna and the pure precepts, one should know that they are only obtained from the fundamental karmic paths, because in samÄdhi there are only fundamental karmic paths.
They are not obtained from the proximate parts before and after, because in the state of concentration there is only the fundamental, and in the state of non-concentration there is no such precept.
Even the prohibited offenses committed by sentient beings do not obtain these two kinds of precepts, let alone the prohibited offenses committed by non-sentient beings.
The phrase â€œfrom the eternalâ€ refers to the past, present, and future.

The obtainment of aggregates, sense bases, and elements is the same as the mind that accompanies these precepts. Because they are not the same, four sentences should be made. There are aggregates, sense bases, and elements that only obtain the precepts of individual liberation, not the other two, etc.
The first case is the present, the proximate and remote preparatory actions, and the offenses that are prohibited.
The second case is the past and future fundamental paths of action.
The third case is the present fundamental paths of action.
The fourth case is the past and future proximate and remote preparatory actions. The terms paths of action and so on are used to refer to their bases.
If it were otherwise, then it would only be said that future restraint is guarded, because it can only prevent future offenses from arising.
It is not that past and present restraint is guarded, because restraint has no function with regard to them.
Do all those who obtain restraint or non-restraint do so equally from all sentient beings, from all aspects, and from all causes?
Not all are equal.
What are their characteristics?
The verse states:ğŸ”½Restraint is said to be indeterminate with regard to all sentient beings, aspects, and causes.
Non-restraint is from all sentient beings, aspects, but not causes.
The treatise says:
Vows are definitely obtained by a well-disciplined intention that universally takes all sentient beings as objects, not by a partial mind that follows evil.
The branches and causes are indefinite. The branches refer to the karmic paths.
First, among the various precepts, there are those obtained from all branches, namely the precepts of bhiká¹£us.
There are those obtained from four branches, namely the other precepts.
There are two kinds of causes that are allowed to be different.
The first is the three kinds of wholesome roots such as non-greed, etc. The second is the difference in the arising of minds such as lower, middle, and upper.
The name of all precepts is based on the first cause, because all causes are present in one mind.
The name of all precepts is based on the second cause, because the lower level, etc. do not arise together.
Here, it is based on the latter three causes.

There is one kind of person who abides in the precepts and obtains the precepts with regard to all sentient beings, but not by all aspects and not by all causes, namely, one who with a lesser, middling, or superior mind receives the precepts of the lay devotee or novice monk.

There is one kind of person who abides in the precepts and obtains the precepts with regard to all sentient beings by all aspects but not by all causes, namely, one who with a lesser, middling, or superior mind receives the precepts of a fully ordained monk.ğŸ”½There is one kind of person who abides in the precepts and obtains the precepts with regard to all sentient beings by all aspects and by all causes, namely, one who with the three kinds of minds receives the precepts of the lay devotee, novice monk, or fully ordained monk.

There is one kind of person who abides in the precepts and obtains the precepts with regard to all sentient beings by all causes but not by all aspects, namely, one who with the three kinds of minds receives the precepts of the lay devotee, the one-day upavÄsa precepts, or the novice monk.
There is no one who does not obtain the precepts with regard to all sentient beings, because the causes have already been explained.
It is not that the evil mind is completely eliminated with respect to some sentient beings.
Now we should consider whether the precepts obtained with respect to the bodies of Buddhas up to ants are different or not.
If they are different, then because the destinies are not fixed, the precepts obtained with respect to sentient beings should increase and decrease.

If they are not different, then why does killing a human being constitute a pÄrÄjika offense, while killing a non-human being only constitutes a sthÅ«lÄtyaya offense, and killing an animal constitutes a duá¹£ká¹›ta offense?
It is not because of the difference in bodies of non-sentient objects that the precepts received also have differences.
However, the reason for the difference in the offenses and karmic retribution should be known to be due only to the difference in the preparatory actions.
The preparatory actions for killing a human being and killing a non-human being, up to killing an ant, all have differences. The precepts are established based on the general intention.

That is, one universally arouses a good thought of non-discrimination toward sentient beings and seeks to obtain the precepts. If one does not abandon the thought of evil toward a single sentient being, one cannot seek to obtain the precepts of individual liberation. Therefore, there is no difference in obtaining the precepts. This is because one who obtains the precepts definitely does not make distinctions regarding individuals, aspects, time, or conditions.

That is, one definitely does not make such distinctions as: Toward a certain sentient being, I abstain from killing, etc.; toward a certain aspect of the precepts, I am able to uphold it; in a certain region, I abstain from killing, etc.; I only do so for a month, etc.; except in the case of war, etc., I am able to abstain from killing, etc. One who receives the precepts in this way does not obtain the precepts, but only precepts that resemble the precepts.
Therefore, there is no difference in the precepts due to the differences in the bodies of sentient beings.

Also, one does not obtain the prÄtimoká¹£a restraint that is included in the fundamental karmic paths with regard to oneâ€™s own body, but it is not blocked in principle that one obtains the subsidiary forms of the karmic paths of killing oneself, etc., and the sins included in the heinous crimes, etc. This means that one excludes the first of the many remaining sins, etc.

Also, this prÄtimoká¹£a restraint that one receives is obtained with regard to all objects, whether able or unable to understand, and one does not obtain this restraint only with regard to able objects, because it is necessary to universally arouse the intention not to harm sentient beings without distinction in order to obtain it.
If one does not accept this, then one cannot kill those who are asleep or in a faint, etc., and therefore one should not be able to obtain the restraint.

If one says that when they recover their original mind, they can be killed again, then this should also be so, because that which is unable to understand can be changed to a able object and then can be killed again.
There is an opinion that

if one obtains this restraint only with regard to able objects, then it should increase or decrease, because able objects and unable objects, the two classes of sentient beings, are subject to change.
This is not a difficulty, because when the object changes, there is no change in the precepts, because the causes for obtaining and losing them are present.
That is, the object that was able to induce precepts may later change and become an object that is unable to induce precepts.
There is no reason to make one lose the precepts that one has obtained. One obtains the precepts in general with regard to all objects that are able to induce them.

If you insist that the precepts are lost or obtained because the object that is able or unable to induce them changes, then the error of the increase or decrease of the precepts would result. Do not grasses, which did not exist, now come to exist? Do not sentient beings eternally enter complete nirvana? Consequently, one would lose or obtain the precepts. However, this does not avoid the error of the increase or decrease of the precepts.
Therefore the previous explanation is correct and free of error.

Also, because the past tathÄgatas and the sentient beings they converted have entered complete nirvana, the buddhas of later ages do not obtain the precepts with regard to them. Consequently, the precepts of later buddhas are fewer than those of earlier buddhas. However, the precepts are not lost or obtained because the object that is able or unable to induce them changes. This is because the precepts are not generated separately with regard to each sentient being.

Also, the precepts of former and later Buddhas are the same in number of items, because the various forms of morality arise from the differences in causes, such as noncovetousness, etc., and each class of items has a single kind of nonmanifest action, which is generally obtained in relation to all sentient beings.
Since this nonmanifest action has no fine divisions, it cannot be analyzed as being small or large. How can it be said that the later is less than the former?

Also, all Buddhas are universally endowed with morality in relation to all sentient beings and with all the items of morality, because the number of items is the same and there are no differences. Therefore, there is no error in saying that the morality of later Buddhas is less than that of former Buddhas.
Also, the qualities of a Buddha are all equal, but this does not refer to those that are impure.
If it were otherwise, there would be increase and decrease in the different states of a single body, not to mention the error of increase and decrease in relation to other bodies.
We have discussed the acquisition of the various moralities.

The acquisition of immorality is definitely related to all sentient beings and to the karmic paths, because there is no immorality in relation to a part of the realm of sentient beings or in relation to incomplete karmic paths.
This concentration does not exist, because there is no simultaneous arising of inferior and superior minds.

If there is a type of person who obtains non-restraint through an inferior mind, and later at another time ends the lives of sentient beings through a superior mind, he only accomplishes the inferior non-restraint, and also accomplishes the superior expression of killing and so on.
The middling and superior should be understood in the same way.

Here, one should consider: In the matter of slaughtering sheep and so on, there are some who only accept one and do not obtain non-restraint. It should not be said that there are also those who obtain it by accepting one matter.
If so, why is there no non-restraint obtained from all causes?

Like those who obtain restraint, even though they have already accepted one of the distinctions in the expression of killing and so on, and later accept another, it is not that non-restraint is newly obtained.

That is to say, first, with regard to all sentient beings, one gives rise to an intention to harm without any restraint, and for the sake of livelihood, one accepts non-restraint. What else is there to obtain at this time?
Therefore, this does not exist from all causes.

However, in the case of the precepts, one who has received the precepts of the faithful and obedient may receive the precepts of the diligent and chaste, and the diligent and chaste may again receive the precepts of the bhiká¹£u. Here, what is called the unwholesome precepts?
It refers to those who slaughter sheep, kill chickens, kill pigs, catch birds, fish, hunt beasts, rob, serve as executioners, guard prisons, bind dragons, cook dogs, and set traps and nets, etc.

The word etc. indicates those who slander, revile, spy for faults, and delight in speaking ill of others, those who pursue an improper livelihood, and kings who administer punishments and penalize crimes. They only constantly harbor harmful thoughts.

They are called those with the unwholesome precepts because they abide in the unwholesome precepts in this way, because they possess the unwholesome precepts, because they practice the unwholesome precepts, because they skillfully create the unwholesome precepts, and because they frequently cultivate the unwholesome precepts. As for the butcher of sheep, it means that for the sake of livelihood, he vows to kill sheep for his entire life.
The rest should be understood accordingly as appropriate.
Butchers of sheep only have a harmful mind towards sheep, not towards other kinds, so how can they obtain non-restraint towards all?
It is reasonable that one obtains all forms of restraint universally in the realm of sentient beings, because one receives it with the superior intention to universally benefit and bring happiness.
Butchers and others who are not restrained do not have the intention to harm their closest relatives, and they do not wish to kill even to save their own lives.
How can it be said that they universally obtain non-restraint towards all?
This is also possible.
Because those who are not restrained universally have a corrupted good intention towards the realm of sentient beings.
Although this is not the case, it is hypothetically said:
If all sentient beings, including one's parents, were to appear in front as sheep, the butcher would universally have a harmful intention towards them all.
That is, they have long cultivated a mind of unrestraint, and even their own relatives are not spared. For the sake of livelihood,

When those of unrestrained conduct receive evil precepts, they must give rise to this kind of violent intention:
Even if my mother and others were to become sheep, I would still kill them, let alone other living beings.
Because of this intention, they obtain unrestrained conduct.

Otherwise, they should only obtain a neutral offense. Because of this, even though they know that their close relatives are not actually sheep in the present, they still have the intention to harm, and thus they completely obtain evil precepts.
Although there are no noble ones who will take on a sheep's body in the future, they still have the intention to harm their close relatives.
The author of the treatise gives this example here:
If one observes the future body of a sheep and so on, and obtains unrestrained conduct towards present relatives and so on.

There is wrong thought and a violent intention:

Although the matter is controlled by sheep, the mind is vast and pervasive. Therefore, it is possible to observe future sheep and also give rise to evil precepts towards present holy relatives. It is not that observing future holy ones and relatives, one does not give rise to evil precepts towards the present body of a sheep.
Or, there is no need for dispute, and the principle should be agreed upon equally.

For example, a butcher who raises sheep, even though in his whole life he does not steal or take what is not given, is content with his own wife and does not speak the four kinds of wrong speech, yet because of the sheep, his wholesome intention is destroyed, and he commits the sin of the seven branches of the unwholesome precepts.

In this way, even though he has no intention to harm his relatives, etc., because his wholesome intention is destroyed due to the sheep, he obtains the unwholesome precepts throughout the realm of sentient beings.

If he first makes a vow to receive the wholesome precepts, and later does not completely destroy his wholesome intention, but only receives killing due to encountering other conditions, he obtains the sin of the middle ground, not the unwholesome precepts.
But if one only obtains the unwholesome precepts, one must completely destroy one's wholesome intention, and thus obtain the seven branches.

Because in the desire realm, the power of unwholesomeness is strong, and an unwholesome intention arises spontaneously. One creates grave evil without needing to make effort.

Because the power of unwholesomeness in the desire realm is strong, even if one does not always commit it, one still obtains evil precepts.
